outline.text: What’s the best way to create a PDF?
You can create PDFs from documents printed on paper, Microsoft Word documents, InDesign®
files, digital images, and more. Diﬀerent types of sources have diﬀerent tools available for PDF
conversion. In many applications, you can create PDFs by selecting the Adobe PDF printer in
the Print dialog box.
If a file is open in its authoring application (such as a spreadsheet that is open in Microsoft
Excel), you can convert it to PDF without opening Adobe Acrobat. Similarly, if Acrobat is
already open, you don’t have to open the authoring application to convert a file to PDF.
Every PDF balances eﬃciency (small file size) and quality (such as resolution and color). If the
balance between the file size and the quality is critical to your task, you must use an
appropriate conversion method.
For example, you can drag files to the Acrobat icon to create PDFs. In this case, Acrobat
applies the most recently used conversion settings without providing access to those settings.
If you want more control over the process, you’ll want to use another method.
PDF creation methods by file type
Refer to the following lists to determine the methods available for the diﬀerent types of files.

Balance PDF file size and quality
You can select various settings to ensure that your PDF has the best balance between file size,
resolution, conformity to specific standards, and other factors. The settings you select depend
on your goals for the PDF that you are creating. For example, a PDF intended for high-quality
commercial printing requires diﬀerent settings than a PDF intended only for onscreen viewing
and quick downloading over the Internet.
Acrobat Distiller Once selected, these settings apply across PDFMaker, Acrobat, and .
However, some settings are limited to specific contexts or file types. For example, PDFMaker
Microsoft Oﬃce options can vary among the diﬀerent types of applications.
For convenience, you can select one of the conversion presets available in Acrobat. You can
also create, define, save, and reuse custom presets that are uniquely suited to your purposes.
For scanned documents, you can choose from Autodetect Color Mode or several scanning
presets that are optimized for scanning documents and images in color or black and white.
You can modify these presets or use your own custom scanning settings.
There are various ways to create a PDF file using Acrobat. You can generate a PDF quickly
using the convert to PDF tool, menu commands, dragging-and-dropping files onto the
Acrobat application icon, or converting clipboard data.
Convert a file to PDF using Acrobat menu
commands
1. Do any of the following:
Create In Acrobat, select from the global toolbar.
Single file The Create a PDF tool opens. On the left rail, is
Select a file selected by default. Choose the button.
Create PDF from File Select the hamburger menu > > (Windows),
File Create PDF from File or > > (macOS).
2. In the Open dialog box, select the ﬁle that you want to convert. You can browse all ﬁle
types or select a speciﬁc type from the Files Of Type drop-down menu.
Advanced settings 3. Optionally, select to change the conversion options if you're
converting an image file to PDF. The options available vary depending on the file type.
Note:
Advanced settings All Files The button is unavailable if you choose as the file type or
if no conversion settings are available for the selected file type. (For example, the
Advanced settings button is unavailable for Microsoft Word and Microsoft Excel files.)
Create 4. Select to convert the ﬁle to a PDF.
Depending on the type of ﬁle being converted, the authoring applica Ɵon opens
automa Ɵcally, or a progress dialog box appears. If the ﬁle is in an unsupported format, a
message appears, telling you that the ﬁle cannot be converted to PDF.
Save Save 5. When the new PDF opens, choose the hamburger menu > or
As File Save File Save As (Windows), > or > (macOS), and then select a name and
location for the PDF.
When naming a PDF that’s intended for electronic distribution, limit the filename to eight
characters (with no spaces) and include the .pdf extension. This action ensures that email
programs or network servers don’t truncate the filename and that the PDF opens as expected.
Convert a file to PDF using the Convert to PDF tool
All tools Convert to PDF 1. In Acrobat, select > .
2. In the file explorer window that appears, select the file you want to convert to PDF,
Open and select .
3. The selected file is converted to PDF and opens in Acrobat. Choose the hamburger
Save Save As File Save File Save As menu > or (Windows), > or > (macOS),
and then select a name and location for the PDF.
Drag-and-drop to create PDFs
This method is best for small, simple files, such as small image files and plain text files, when
the balance between file size and output quality is not important. You can use this technique
with many other types of files, but you cannot adjust any conversion settings during the
process.
1. Select the icons of one or more files in the Windows Explorer or macOS Finder.
2. Drag the file icons onto the Acrobat application icon. Or (Windows only) drag the files
into the open Acrobat window.
If a message appears saying that the file could not be opened in Acrobat, then that
file type cannot be converted to PDF by the drag-and-drop method. Use one of the
other conversion methods for that file.
You can also convert PostScript and EPS files to PDF by dragging them onto
the Acrobat window or the Acrobat application icon.
3. Save the PDF.
Windows Explorer Convert (Windows only) You can also right-click a file in and select
to Adobe PDF .
Convert clipboard content to PDF
You can create PDFs from text and images that you copy from applications on macOS or
Windows.
1. Capture content in the Clipboard:
Use the copy command in the applications. •
PrintScreen Press the key (Windows). •
Applications Utilities Screenshot Use the Screenshot utility ( > > ), and •
Edit Copy choose > to place the content on the clipboard (macOS).
All In a PDF file, you can select objects using the Edit Object tool ( •
tools Use print production Edit object > > ), and then copy the selected
objects.
Create Clipboard Create All tools Create a 2. In Acrobat, choose > > , or choose >
PDF Clipboard Create > > .
The PDF from Clipboard command appears only when content is copied to the
Clipboard. If the Clipboard is empty, the command is disabled.
Create a blank PDF
You can create a blank PDF, rather than beginning with a file, a clipboard image, or scanning.
This process can be useful for creating a one-page PDF. For longer, more complex, or heavily
formatted documents, it’s better to create the source document in an application that offers
Microsoft Word more layout and formatting options, such as Adobe InDesign or .
Do any of the following:
Create In Acrobat, select from the global bar.
Blank page Create The Create a PDF tool opens. On the le Ō rail, select , and then select .
Create Blank Page Select the hamburger menu > > (Windows),
File Create Blank Page or > > (macOS).
Acrobat creates a blank page PDF.
Edit Organize To add a blank page to an existing PDF, open the PDF and then choose >
pages Insert Blank page > > .
Create multiple PDFs from multiple files
You can create multiple PDFs from multiple native files, including files of different supported
formats, in one operation. This method is useful when you must convert a large number of files
to PDF.
Note : When you use this method, Acrobat applies the most recently used conversion settings
without offering you access to those settings. If you want to adjust the conversion settings, do
so before using this method.
Create 1. In Acrobat, select from the global bar.
Mul Ɵple ﬁles Create mul Ɵple 2. The Create a PDF tool opens. On the le Ō rail, select >
PDF ﬁles Next , and then select .
Add Files Add Files Add Folders 3. Choose > or , and then select the ﬁles or folder.
OK 4. Select . The Output op Ɵons dialog box appears.
Output Op Ɵons 5. In the dialog box, specify your target folder and ﬁlename
OK preferences, and then select .
Using PDFMaker within an authoring application is a simple, one-click procedure. It involves
clicking an Acrobat PDFMaker toolbar button or choosing a command on the Adobe PDF menu.
About Acrobat PDFMaker
PDFMaker is an Acrobat feature that operates within many business applications, such as
Microsoft Office applications, AutoCAD, and Lotus Notes. When you install Acrobat,
PDFMaker controls appear in the work area of the authoring application.
Note: Some PDFMaker features are not available in certain versions of the authoring
applications. For a comparison chart, see Compatible web browsers and PDFMaker
applications | Acrobat, Reader .
Using Create PDF cloud service for PDF
conversion
Acrobat provides an option to use Adobe Create PDF cloud service in addition to a local
conversion to convert Microsoft Word documents to PDFs. The created PDFs are high-quality
and provide exceptional visual fidelity. They are well-tagged for better accessibility. They also
include link recognition so that hyperlinks, internal document links, and tables of contents are
created as live links.
Convert a file to PDF using PDFMaker
Adobe PDF In Windows, Acrobat installs both an Acrobat PDFMaker toolbar and an menu in
Adobe many popular authoring applications. You can use either the toolbar buttons or the
PDF Action menu (the menu in Lotus Notes) to create PDFs, but the menu also provides access
to conversion settings. Although many of the conversion options are common to all authoring
applications, a few are application-specific.
For Microsoft Office applications such as Word, Excel, and PowerPoint, the options for creating
Acrobat PDFs are available from the ribbon.
If you don’t see the PDF toolbar buttons in an application, you must show or activate the PDF
toolbar. For other troubleshooting issues, see Troubleshoot Acrobat PDFMaker Problems.
Show or activate PDFMaker in Microsoft Office and Lotus Notes
If the PDF toolbar buttons don’t appear in your Microsoft Office or Lotus Notes application, use
one of the following methods to show or activate PDFMaker.
File Preferences For Lotus Notes 9, choose > . In the dialog box that appears,
Toolbar Toolbars Acrobat PDFMaker choose > , and select the Visible option for .
For Microsoft Office, follow these steps:
File Options 1. Select the tab, and then choose .
2. Select Add-Ins on the left side of the dialog box.
3. Do one of the following:
Acrobat PDFMaker Office COM Add-in If PDFMOutlook or isn't listed, choose
Go COM Add-Ins from the Manage pop-up menu and select .
Acrobat PDFMaker Office COM Add-in If PDFMOutlook or is listed under
Disabled Application Add-ins, select Disabled Items from the Manage pop-up
Go menu and select .
Acrobat PDFMaker Office COM Add-in OK 4. Select PDFMOutlook or and select .
5. Restart the Office application.
Convert a file to PDF
1. Open the file in the application used to create it.
Convert To Adobe PDF Acrobat PDFMaker 2. Select the button on the toolbar.
For Microsoft Office applications, such as Word, Excel, and PowerPoint, select
Create PDF Acrobat the button on the ribbon.
Save 3. Enter a filename and location for the PDF, and select .
View Result Protect PDF 4. (Optional) Check to open the PDF or enable to specify
Security the settings for the PDF.
Create a PDF and share the link for viewing or commenting
Applicable to Microsoft Word, Excel, and PowerPoint
2. Do any of the following:
Home Create PDF and share link From the tab, choose .
File Share Create PDF and share link Create PDF and Share link Select > > > .

You can share the link with the desired recipients.
Create a PDF and share via Outlook
Home Create PDF and Share via Outlook From the tab, choose .
Acrobat Create PDF and Share via Outlook From the tab, choose .
File Share Email Create PDF and Share via Outlook Select > > > .

the link in a new message draft.
4. You can edit the message as desired, add the recipient's email addresses, and then
Send select .
Create a PDF as an email attachment
Adobe PDF Convert To Adobe PDF And Email 2. Choose > .
For Microsoft Office applications, such as Word, Excel, and PowerPoint, click
Create And Share Acrobat the button on the ribbon.

Acrobat Attach as Adobe PDF 1. In the Outlook email Message window, click > button.
Open 2. Select a file to attach, and click .

(Outlook)

PDF button .

Browse Open 2. Click , select a file to convert, and click .

Restrict Access Only To To specify only users that receive the PDF, select

4. If prompted, enter your user name and password to log in to the Adobe

Create a PDF and send it for review
Convert To Adobe PDF And Send For Review 2. Click the button on the Acrobat
Adobe PDF Convert To Adobe PDF And PDFMaker toolbar, or (if available) choose >
Send For Review .
Identity Setup 3. When the dialog box appears, enter the appropriate information
Complete about yourself, and click .
4. Follow the directions in the wizard that appears, as described in Start an email-based

Create a PDF and run an action
Convert To Adobe PDF And Run Action 2. Click the button on the Acrobat PDFMaker
Adobe PDF Convert To Adobe PDF And Run Action toolbar, or (if available) choose > .
For Microsoft Office 2010 applications such as Word, Excel, and PowerPoint, click
Create PDF And Run Action Acrobat the button on the ribbon.
3. Click an action to from the button menu, and follow the onscreen prompts to save
the files.
4. The PDF opens in Acrobat. Click Start in the right-hand pane to process the file.
View PDFMaker conversion settings
PDFMaker conversion settings vary according to file types. For example, the options available
for PowerPoint files aren’t the same as the options available for Outlook files. Once you’ve
selected conversion settings, those choices apply to all subsequent PDFs you create from that
file type. It’s a good idea to review the settings occasionally.
1. Open a PDFMaker-enabled application (such as Word or Excel).
2. Do one of the following:
Change Adobe PDF Conversion Settings (Lotus Notes) Choose Actions > .
Acrobat Adobe PDF (Office 2010 applications) In the or ribbon,
Preferences click .
Adobe PDF Change Conversion Settings (All other applications) Choose > .
Restore Defaults 3. (Optional) To revert to the original default settings, click on
Settings the tab.
Settings tab of the Adobe PDFMaker preferences
The settings available for PDFMaker depend on the application in which you’re using
PDFMaker.
Conversion Settings
Specifies the standard by which the PDF will be optimized. When you choose an item in the
menu, a description of that preset appears immediately below it.
View Adobe PDF Result
Convert To Opens the converted document directly into Acrobat. (Exception: when you choose
Adobe PDF And Email .)
Prompt For Adobe PDF File Name
Lets you enter a custom filename for the resulting PDF. Deselect this option to save the file in
the same folder as the source file, using the same name but with a .pdf extension.
Convert Document Information
Properties Adds document information from the dialog box of the source file. This setting
Advanced Adobe PDF overrides the printer preferences and settings in the panel of the
Settings dialog box.
Advanced Settings Adobe PDF Settings The button opens the dialog box, which contains many
additional conversion options. These conversion settings apply to all Acrobat features that
create PDFs, such as Acrobat Distiller, PDFMaker, and the Acrobat application itself.
PDF/A Compliance
Creates the PDF so that it conforms to the selected ISO standard for long-term preservation of
electronic documents.
Security tab of the Adobe PDFMaker preferences
Require A Password To Open The Document
Document Open Password When selected, makes the option available, where you enter a
password that users must use to open the document.
Restrict Editing And Printing Of The Document
Permissions When selected, makes the other options available.
Change Permissions Password
Specifies a password you set that users must use in order to do any allowable printing or
editing.
Printing Allowed
Permissions Password Specifies whether users who use the can print the document and at
what resolution.
Changes Allowed
Permissions Password Specifies what changes users who use the can make.
Enable Copying Of Text, Images, And Other Contents
Prevents or allows users from copying from the PDF.
Enable Text Access For Screen Reader Devices For The Visually Impaired
Prevents or allows screen reader devices to read text. (Selected by default.)
Enable Plaintext Metadata
Specifies whether the search engine can read the document metadata. Available only when the
PDF-compatibility is set to Acrobat 6.0 (PDF 1.5) or later.
Convert Microsoft Word, PowerPoint, and
Excel files to PDF
When creating a PDF from Microsoft Word, PowerPoint, or Excel, you can set conversion
options for the current file. You can also select a range of content in the file to convert. The
conversion options that you can set in the following steps are some of the most commonly used
Acrobat PDFMaker settings from the dialog box. Any changes you make to the conversion
options apply to the current conversion only.
Convert Excel files to PDF
1. Open a file in Excel.
2. Optionally, select the cells to convert.
Acrobat Create 3. From the ribbon, select one of the options.
Acrobat PDFMaker Conversion Range 4. In the dialog box, select a , then
Convert To PDF choose .
Save Adobe PDF File As 5. In the dialog box, specify a filename and location for the PDF.
Options 6. Optionally, select the button to change the conversion settings.
Save 7. Select to create the PDF.
Convert Word and PowerPoint files to PDF
1. Open a file in Word or PowerPoint.
2. Optionally, select objects and text (Word) or slides (PowerPoint), as needed.
3. (Office 2010) From the Acrobat ribbon, select Create PDF, Create And Attach to Email,
or Create And Send For Review.
Save Adobe PDF File As 4. In the dialog box, specify a filename and location for the PDF.
Options 5. Optionally, click the button to change the conversion settings.
Page Range Slide Range 6. Select a (Word) or (PowerPoint). The Selection option is
available only if you have selected content in the file.
OK Save 7. Click , then click to create the PDF.
Convert email messages to PDFs
You can use PDFMaker to convert one or more Microsoft Outlook or Lotus Notes email
PDF Portfolio PDF messages or entire folders of messages to a merged PDF or . Within a
Portfolio , each email message appears as a separate PDF file.
Acrobat PDFMaker Conversion Settings The dialog box contains the option that determines
PDF whether email messages are merged into one continuous PDF or assembled into a
Portfolio .
The controls that activate an email conversion to PDF appear in two places within the email
Acrobat PDFMaker application: on the toolbar and on a menu. In Outlook, the menu is
Adobe PDF called and appears to the right of the Outlook Help menu. In Lotus Notes, PDF
commands appear under the Actions menu.
PDF Portfolio You can convert one currently open email message to PDF (not to a ) by
File Print Adobe PDF Print choosing > , and selecting as the printer in the dialog box. The
PDFMaker conversion settings do not affect this process.
Specify whether email messages become merged PDFs or PDF
Portfolios
1. Do one of the following:
Acrobat Change Conversion Settings (Outlook) Choose > .
To convert and merge email messages into a PDF as sequential pages of one
Output Adobe PDF Portfolio When Creating A New PDF document, deselect
File .
PDF Portfolio To assemble converted email messages as components of a ,
Output Adobe PDF Portfolio When Creating A New PDF File select .

Acrobat Convert To Adobe PDF 1. Choose > .
Note: You can also convert a different file to PDF from within an open Outlook email message if
Attach As Adobe PDF the toolbar is shown. Clicking this button opens a series of dialog boxes

Convert email messages to a new PDF
1. In Outlook or Lotus Notes, select the individual email messages.
Acrobat Selected Messages Create New PDF (Outlook) Choose > > .
Convert Selected Messages To Adobe PDF (Lotus Notes) Choose Actions > .
Save Adobe PDF As 3. In the dialog box, select a location, type a filename, and

Note: Do not type a new name for the PDF. If you do, a warning message appears
OK telling you that the PDF was not found. Click , and select a PDF without changing

4. (Outlook only) If a message appears, alerting you that the existing PDF was created

PDF Portfolio Yes To create a from the original PDF archive, click , and select a

Convert email folders to a new PDF
PDFMaker can convert multiple folders to PDF in one procedure. It is not necessary to select the
folders at the beginning of the process because you can select them in a dialog box that
appears automatically.
Acrobat Selected Folders Create New PDF (Outlook) Choose > > .

Convert Folder(s) To PDF 2. In the dialog box, select the folders. Then select or deselect

Add To add other email folders to the list, click and select the folder.
Delete To remove folders from the list, select the folders and click .
Change To change an archive file, select any folder name from the list, click
Archive File , and specify the name and location.
Run Archival Now To start archiving email immediately, click .
Create PDFs from Word mail merges
Mail merges from Word generate documents like form letters—for one common example—
that are personalized with information like the names and addresses of the recipients. With
Acrobat PDFMaker, you can save steps by using a Word mail merge document and
corresponding data file to output mail merges directly to PDF. You can even set up PDFMaker to
attach those PDFs to email messages that are generated during the PDF-creation process.
For information on setting up files for the Word Mail Merge feature, see Microsoft Office Word
Help.
1. In Microsoft Word, open the template that you have created as the basis of your mail
merge, or create the file using the Word Mail Merge toolbar and Mail Merge wizard,
as needed.
Note: Do not complete the mail merge in Word. Instead, set up and preview the mail
merge as usual, so that you can verify that the merge will work correctly.
Acrobat Mail Merge Choose > .
Mail Merge To Adobe PDF Click the button on the Mail Merge toolbar (View >
Toolbars > Mail Merge).
Acrobat PDFMaker - Mail Merge 3. In the dialog box, select the options you want:
To specify which records in the data file will be imported into the merged
All Current files, select or , or enter a range of pages by typing in
From To the and boxes.
Specify PDF File Name To name the PDF that will be created, type in the box.
Note: The PDF will be named using this text plus a series of numbers. For example, if
JulyLetter
Specify PDF File Name you type in the box, the mail-merged PDFs
might appear as JulyLetter_0000123, JulyLetter_0000124, JulyLetter_0000125, and
so forth.
Automatically Send Adobe PDF Files By Emai 4. For l, do one of the following:
To create and save merged PDFs for printing or sending later in email, leave
OK the option deselected, and click .
To create merged PDFs and attach each one to an email message to the
appropriate recipient, select this check box, and fill in the other Email options.
Browse For Folder 5. When the dialog box appears, navigate to the location you want
OK to use and click .
Status indicators appear as PDFMaker generates the individual PDFs,
Automatically Send Adobe PDF Files By Email 6. If you selected , a dialog box appears
OK asking for your email profile. Enter the appropriate information and click .
When the job has finished, a message appears, telling you that the process was successful.
Email options for PDF mail merges
Use the pop-up menu to select the field or column in the associated data file that contains the
email addresses in each individual’s record.
Subject Line
Type the text that you want to appear in the subject line of each message.
Message
Type to add or edit text that you want to appear in the body of the email messages.
Convert Visio files to PDF (Acrobat Pro)
PDFs created from Visio files preserve page sizes and support layers, searchable text, custom
properties, links, bookmarks, and comments, depending on the conversion settings. To specify
the properties
Acrobat Preferences (Visio 2010) From the ribbon choose >
When you convert your Visio file, only shapes and guides that are printable and visible in the
Visio drawing are converted and appear in the PDF. Shapes are converted regardless of their
protection or behavior. Shape custom properties can be converted to PDF object data.
When you convert the Visio file to a PDF, you can preserve all or just some layers, or you can
flatten all layers. If you flatten layers, the PDF will look like the original drawing, but won’t
contain any layer information. When flattened, the contents of only visible and printable layers
will appear in the converted PDF.
Convert Visio files
1. If you want to change the PDFMaker conversion settings, do the following. (For
information about a setting, place the pointer over the setting to display a tool tip
below.)
Acrobat Preferences (Visio 2010) Choose >
2. If you want to convert each page in the Visio file to a bookmarked page in the PDF
Adobe PDF Convert All Pages In Drawing file, choose > . If this option is deselected,
only the current page is converted.
Acrobat Create PDF (Visio 2010) Choose > .
Acrobat Convert To Adobe PDF (Visio 2010) Choose > .
Acrobat Create and Attach To Email (Visio 2010) Choose > . The PDF file
attaches to a new email message in your default email application.
Acrobat Create and Send For Review (Visio 2010) Choose > . The file converts
to an Adobe PDF file, and an email-based review process begins.
4. If you want to include the custom properties of shapes, select that option.
Continue 5. Click .
6. Select a layers option to retain or flatten layers in the resulting PDF, and
Continue click .
